keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator, won the Bolivian presidential election with 54.5% of the vote, defeating former president Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, who received 45.5%.
Paz’s victory marks the end of 20 years of rule by the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party, signaling a major political transformation in Bolivia.
The electorate, especially in rural and working-class areas, was disillusioned with MAS’s economic policies, leading to a shift toward a centrist alternative.
Paz’s campaign emphasized a return to economic stability through market reforms, including ending the fixed exchange rate, phasing out fuel subsidies, and reducing public investment.
Despite his centrist platform, Paz has faced criticism for vague promises of social support during economic restructuring, raising concerns about feasibility and inflation risks.
Rodrigo Paz’s running mate, ex-police captain Edman Lara, gained popularity through social media and anti-corruption activism, bringing a new energy to the campaign.
The election result reflects a clear class divide: Paz won rural and Indigenous voter bases, while Quiroga won affluent urban and agro-industrial areas.
Paz has pledged to improve relations with the United States, reversing past tensions following Morales’ expulsion of U.S. officials in 2008 and 2009.
Bolivia faces significant challenges, including depleted foreign currency reserves, inflation at 23% (year-on-year), and fuel shortages, which must be addressed before Paz assumes office.
Paz’s victory is seen as a turning point in Bolivia’s economic and political trajectory, with potential for both stability and renewed social unrest.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator, has been elected president of Bolivia in a decisive victory over former president Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, marking the end of 20 years of rule by the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party. With 54.5% of the vote, Paz’s win reflects widespread public anger over record inflation, fuel shortages, and economic mismanagement under MAS. His campaign, backed by rural and working-class voters, promotes a return to market-based reforms, including ending the fixed exchange rate and cutting fuel subsidies. However, he faces significant economic challenges, including depleted foreign reserves and inflation at 23%, and criticism over vague promises of social support. His running mate, former police officer Edman Lara, brought new energy through anti-corruption activism, though their campaign was marked by tensions. Paz’s victory signals a sharp political and economic shift, with hopes of restoring U.S. relations and ushering in a new era of governance. The new administration will take office on November 8, 2025, with the challenge of stabilizing the economy and maintaining social cohesion.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivian Presidential Election, Marking End of MAS Rule
